title: Problem Overview
content: This header documents **Erdős Problem #213** about integer distance sets in general position. The question asks whether for all n ≥ 4, we can find n points with no three collinear, no four concyclic, and all distances integers.
mathContext: The 'general position' requirements (no three collinear, no four concyclic) prevent trivial infinite constructions. Anning-Erdős proved such sets must be finite; n=7 is the current record.

title: Point Type
content: We use **EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)** as our representation of points in the plane. This is Mathlib's standard type for finite-dimensional Euclidean spaces.
mathContext: abbrev Point := EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2). This provides the metric structure we need for distances.

title: Collinearity
content: Three points are **collinear** if one is a linear combination of the others (they lie on a common line). **NoThreeCollinear** requires no three distinct points from the set are collinear.
mathContext: AreCollinear uses vector differences: r - p = t • (q - p) means r lies on the line through p and q. NoThreeCollinear applies this to all triples.

title: Concyclicity
content: Four points are **concyclic** (or cocircular) if they lie on a common circle. **NoFourConcyclic** forbids any four distinct points from the set lying on a circle.
mathContext: AreConcyclic p q r s := ∃ center radius, radius > 0 and all four points are at distance radius from center. This is the standard definition of four points on a circle.

title: Integer Distances
content: A set has **integer distances** if for every pair of distinct points, the Euclidean distance is an integer. Combined with general position, this is a severe constraint.
mathContext: AllDistancesInteger S := S.Pairwise (fun p q => ∃ n : ℤ, dist p q = n). IsIntegerDistanceSetGP combines all three conditions. ExistsIntDistSetGP n asserts existence of an n-point set.

title: Anning-Erdős Theorem
content: **Anning-Erdős (1945)** proved a fundamental finiteness result: any set in the plane with no three collinear and all distances integers must be finite. This doesn't even need the concyclic condition!
mathContext: axiom anning_erdos_finite : ∀ S, NoThreeCollinear S → AllDistancesInteger S → S.Finite. This is why finding large examples is hard.

title: Main Question
content: **Erdős Problem #213** asks: for all n ≥ 4, does ExistsIntDistSetGP n hold? That is, can we always find n points satisfying all the constraints? This remains OPEN.
mathContext: Erdos213Question := ∀ n ≥ 4, ExistsIntDistSetGP n. The status is axiomatized as 'open' since neither proof nor disproof is known.

title: Harborth's Construction
content: **Harborth** proved that n=5 is achievable by explicitly constructing 5 points in general position with integer distances.
mathContext: axiom harborth_five : ExistsIntDistSetGP 5. The explicit coordinates involve Pythagorean triples.

title: Kreisel-Kurz Record
content: **Kreisel and Kurz (2008)** achieved the current record: n=7. Their 'integral heptagon' has no three collinear, no four concyclic, and all 21 pairwise distances are integers.
mathContext: axiom kreisel_kurz_seven : ExistsIntDistSetGP 7. This has been the record for over 15 years. n=8 remains unknown.

title: Derived Existence Theorems
content: From the n=7 construction, we prove n=4,5,6 exist by taking subsets. A subset of a set in general position is still in general position, and inherits integer distances.
mathContext: exists_four, exists_six are axioms; exists_five, exists_seven are theorems referencing the axioms. The predicates are preserved under taking subsets.

title: Sparsity Bound
content: **Greenfeld-Iliopoulou-Peluse (2024)** proved that integer distance sets in general position in [-N,N]² have size at most O((log N)^C). This extreme sparsity shows such sets are rare.
mathContext: axiom gip_sparsity_bound : ∃ C > 0, for all S in [-N,N]² satisfying the conditions, |S| ≤ (log N)^C. This is an unconditional bound (no Bombieri-Lang needed).

title: Summary
content: The summary theorem combines all known constructions: n=4,5,6,7 all exist. The open question is whether n=8 or larger is achievable.
